title: Windgather Rocks Walking Route

images.title: Bill Boaden / Fivelane-ends
images.caption: Fivelane-ends. Taken from Windgather Rocks. The crag was featured in the first guide to rock climbing in the Peak District, Some Gritstone Climbs, published in 1913 and written by John Laycock.

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Windgather Rocks
images.caption: Windgather Rocks Viewed from path to Taxal Edge

images.title: Ian Balcombe [CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)]
images.caption: The rocks from top to bottom. Looking up the gritstone crag from below. Popular with climbers despite being only "short". The overhang centre-left provides the crux to "Portfolio", the most famous climb on the crag.

images.title: Colin Park / Windgather Rocks - View looking north
images.caption: Wonderful view looking north from the rocks.

images.title: Jonathan Clitheroe / Rhododendrons on Taxal Moor
images.caption: Rhododendrons on Taxal Moor. This view is looking north from Taxal Edge towards Whaley Bridge on a fine Sunday in mid June. This area is located just north of the rocks.

images.title: steven ruffles / Looking down from Taxal Edge
images.caption: Looking down from Taxal Edge. Derbyshire/Cheshire border.

images.title: Path on the edge of Ladbitch Wood by Peter Barr, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path on the edge of Ladbitch Wood, just east of the rocks. Ladbitch is part of the Goyt Forest.

images.title: Goyt Forest by Peter McDermott, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Goyt Forest. The view south of the rocks.

description: This walk visits this interesting gritstone crag which is popular with rock climbers. There are fascinating geological rock formations and wonderful views over the Peak District to enjoy. The walk starts from Whaley Bridge, near the train train station in the town. You then follow footpaths around the pretty Toddbrook Reservoir before climbing to Taxal Moor. From here you can enjoy super views back towards Whaley Bridge and the reservoir. The final section takes you along Taxal Edge to the rocks where you can enjoy splendid views over the surrounding countryside. The walk can be extended by continuing south to Shining Tor and Cats Tor. It's a great ridge walk with more wide ranging views. Also nearby are Errwood Reservoir and Fernilee Reservoirs where you can enjoy waterside trails.
